<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 171, 292]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 292]]<|/det|> **0625/52** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 313]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **October/November 2017** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 320, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 354]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 584, 374]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 392, 388, 406]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 781, 433]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 330, 447]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 616, 462]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 489]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 515]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 905, 544]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and about 15 minutes on question 4. Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 768, 559]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 584]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 759, 598]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 648, 905, 842]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will compare the oscillations of two pendulums. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 1.1 and 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 109, 769, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 389, 341, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[625, 389, 693, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1. This pendulum has a spherical pendulum bob.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 467, 144, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 875, 486]]<|/det|>
Adjust the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured to the bottom of the bob is \(50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly how to use the set-square to avoid a parallax (line of sight) error when measuring the distance \(d\). You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 761, 917, 780]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 791, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of a pendulum can be determined by measuring the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations and then calculating the period. Some students are asked to explain the reason for this method being more accurate than measuring the time taken for one oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 690, 152]]<|/det|>
Tick the box next to the sentence that gives the best explanation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 155, 198, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 163, 662, 181]]<|/det|>
The method eliminates errors from the measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 195, 761, 213]]<|/det|>
The method is more accurate because the experiment is repeated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 227, 789, 244]]<|/det|>
The method includes more readings so there is less chance for errors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 258, 895, 275]]<|/det|>
The method reduces the effect of errors when starting and stopping the stopwatch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 273, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 144, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 336]]<|/det|>

use of a reference point to aid counting

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 552, 695, 570]]<|/det|>
viewing the rule at right angles when measuring the length

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 318, 705, 337]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 146, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(h)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 581, 141, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
